frontdescription: How my team helped transform communities by creating access to design.
detaildescription: How my team helped transform communities by creating access to design.

body.title: My Role
body.information: Whenever I think about my career as a designer, I always recall this episode of The Simpsons I saw while growing up. It’s 1999 and there is widespread chaos due to Y2K. The Simpsons finds a letter about a rocket that will be sending humanity’s “best and brightest” to preserve human civilization on Mars. Lisa and Marge gets onto the ship but Homer and Bart are left behind. In a desperate attempt to flee the Earth, they board an unguarded rocketship that was actually headed towards the sun.
body.imageTitle: Life's a Glitch, Then You Die
body.imageDesc: Waiting on line to board the ship included several people such as Bill Gates, Jimmy Carter, Stephen Hawking, Michael Jordan and Michelle Kwan.
body.information2: One day, my manager reached out to explained to me about a role on this new initiative within Adaptive Path dedicated to transforming communities by design.
body.information3: Before my manager could finish, I recalled that same episode and telling myself I better make it to that ship to Mars. This was my chance at improving society through design and before I even fully understood the scope of the project, I had became the visual designer for Adaptive Path’s Design in Residence program.

body.title: Design should not be a luxury
body.information: Over the last decade, design had manage to squeeze itself to the forefront of organizations and proved it’s value at the table. However, it is still an expensive piece of the process and having a functional product is still more widely valued than a well designed product.
body.information2: Design in Residence is a program my team and I kicked off to provide UX consultancy to local businesses and organizations that would otherwise not afford it. Adaptive Path set out to reach Start Small Think Big, a local non-profit agency that provides legal, financial, and marketing services to moderate income entrepreneurs.

body.title: Understanding the Client's Needs
body.information: Start Small Think Big reached out to Adaptive Path asking our design team to improve their customer in-take process.
body.information2: We scheduled a phone call with the client to learn about their request, along with asking them to provide more information on their existing process. We learned that the existing process was a series of long and tedious forms before they are provided with any legal, financial, or marketing consultancy. It was people heavy, reactionary, and lacked an integrated process.
body.imageDesc: The agency provided legal, financial, and marketing consultancy to moderate income neighborhood entrepreneurs. They have helped people start bakeries and other small businesses.
body.imageDesc2: Based on the initial conversation with the client, we mapped out what we knew of the full experience. This included client, associate, and backend facing actions. We also marked it with follow up questions for our on-site visit.

body.title: The Design in Residence Team
body.information: We were from New York and San Francisco. We stretched across different teams within the company and we were skilled in different disciplines of design. I worked along Natalie Khun, the lead designer, to provide any visuals and UI needs throughout the project. However, my role quickly changed into that of a service designer as we began to identify the problem.

body.title: Identifying the Larger Problem
body.information: With only a total of 40 hours and no developers, we understood right away that there would be no tangible solution to hand off to our client (at least not a digital product). We would not be able to redesign their intake form in the time available.  Rather than delivering an unfinished product, we decided that it was better use of our time to help Start Small Think Big figure out their problem, while teaching them design thinking and methodologies to solve it themselves. This would not only help them solve their client intake process, but any additional pain points they may find in the future.
body.imageDesc: We prepared a notetaking kit to bring with us to Start Small Think Big’s office :)
body.imageDesc2: Located in Harlem, New York, Start Small Think Big had a very inviting WeWork space they worked out of.
body.imageDesc3: We brought in a physical version of the service blueprint to walk over with Start Small Think Big to make sure we captured all the key components.

body.title: Problem Points
body.information: Through a combination of reviewing their intake process, tools that they used (such as Salesforce and Tableau), and with an in person study of their daily work day at the office, we were able to identify a few key problems:
body.imageTitle: A third perspective of their intake process.
body.imageDesc: Understanding the existing process was key to a redesign. We mapped out tools they used on the backend, alongside the client facing process starting from the application to the WeWork space. We wanted to capture all of the painpoints.

body.title: Service Blueprinting and Teaching Design
body.information: Reminding ourselves that we had a hard stop at 40 hours, we wanted to prepare a design jam with the intent of creating access to design for the client. I worked alongside another design to build out the service blueprint while other designers worked on the presentation.
body.information2: The service blueprint highlighted client and associate facing actions, along with the location of each action in the backend. This provided the client with a full view of their process, enabling them to point out pain points.

body.title: Design Jam
body.information: We set up the room with a giant print out of the service blueprint, with the intention for the client to scribble all over it. To get the client’s honest thoughts and opinions, we got them comfortable in the room by encouraging shameless indulging in KitKats and gummy bears. We initiated with an introduction, along with warm up stretches and casual conversations.
body.information2: With the positive atmosphere set up, we kicked off the presentation.
body.imageDesc: During the session, we learned that the representatives of the financial, legal, and marketing services were not talking to each other about their painpoints. By having them together in a room, they were able to express what was important and crucial in their process to each other. Building a comfortable atmosphere was key to our success.

body.title: Conclusion
body.information: The design jam wrapped up the remaining time we were allowed to spend on this project. Adaptive Path followed up with Start Small Think Big and we had very positive feedback from their team. We were able to successfully teach legal, financial, and marketing consultants design thinking methodologies. By using incorporating design thinking into their process, they would be able to better serve their clients, and better serve our communities.
body.imageDesc: We learned they had placed the service blueprint on their wall and it has encouraged their team to openly discuss pain points as they work together to solve their intake process.

body.title: Epilogue
body.information: Capital One is a large company, and we don’t often get the chance to work with designers across various teams. Design in Residence allowed me to meet other designers who would work outside my discipline (product design) and allowed me to broaden my skillset.
body.information2: I became the poster child of the program, and eventually promoting the program across the company and encouraging the program to expand beyond just design, but to developers and product managers as well.
body.information3: Not only did this project allowed me to expand my knowledge as a designer, it also gave me the opportunity to do good for our communities. Design isn’t just about making beautiful and functional products, it’s a methodology that can be applied to solve problems.

frontdescription: How starting small allowed us to create large enough impacts to move mountains.
detaildescription: How starting small allowed us to create large enough impacts to move mountains.

body.title: My Role
body.information: As a product designer at Capital One, I owned bank account opening experiences under the Customer Account Management team. My role consisted of exploring conceptual ideas as well as providing iterative updates to the existing application.
body.information2: I work alongside various PMs, engineering teams, data analysts, content strategists, researchers, legal/compliance teams, and other designers to build upon the account opening experience across responsive web and our native apps.

body.title: The Challenge
body.information: The account opening process touches millions of customers and act as a door to Capital One. Any changes to the entrance can be risky and affect various lanes across the organization.
body.information2: How do you design and represent the ideal customer experience, while capturing sensitive information, preventing fraudsters, abiding to legal and compliance, and navigating around a secured and complex tech infrastructure?

body.warning: Due to the nature of this work, the content is password is protected. Please contact me if you are interested in viewing this case study.

body.title: Defining a Problem
body.information: Admittingly, when the project came across my desk there was no defined problem and I was tasked with updating the aesthetics. As I began identifying various flaws and pushed for changes, I quickly learned the massive complexities in the system architecture and that creating a better experience wasn’t as simple as making it prettier.
body.imageDesc: Our design team have always been aware of this sign on experience, and have since taken this down. But as you can see, we had a different sign in / sign up experience across the various products Capital One supports.
body.information2: Without a consistent design language, and different applications for different types of products, it was difficult for us to holistically look at the complex web of experiences to identifying common pain points.
body.information3: Before we were able to do any design initiatives, I worked closely with my PM to update all of our applications under the most recent design available.
body.imageDesc2: For a period of time, the account opening experience was not a design led initiative. The engineering teams did not have access to a designer and focused on ensuring functionality.

body.title: Building Relationships
body.information: In order to digest all the problems from technology constraints to legality needs, I got familar with the barista and started building relationships with key stakeholders from product management and engineering. In order to navigate through the complexities, I wanted to understand why each component was placed to begin with.
body.information2: Through talking to engineering, I learned that our info hierarchy was constraint by the locations of various security APIs. Any changes would be a lengthly and costly process, and if I wanted to do any changes, I would have to make them incrementally.
body.information3: Until our engineering teams could revamp and build a modular data structure, we would have to work within the constraints of the skeleton. Fortunately, our engineering team was in the process of migrating code to Angular 2, and I saw the opportunity to include design in the conversation.
body.imageDesc: In order to fully visualize the experience, I initiated a living service blueprint through a collaboration tool called MURAL. I encouraged our partners to help me document each page a customer views, thoughts and feelings, analytics, associate and call center involvement, and the location of where each of our APIs was being called.
body.imageDesc2: To gain insights on our customers, I connected and visited associates across the nation. My team and I visited various branches up and down major east coast cities such as New York and Washington DC, suburban neighborhoods in Wilmington, Delaware, and west coast cities like San Francisco.

body.title: Building with Design Guidelines
body.information: The account opening application had a different customer experience than marketing and post-account opening. There was a need to update the account opening experience to keep a consistent experience across all features.
body.imageDesc: We wanted to ensure that all the design requirements were up to date. However, the code infrastructure was unchanged and all designs created needed to be within the realm of the tech architecture.

body.title: Untested Territories
body.information: My decision to bring a design language to the application was not unchallenged. There were concerns (and very legitimate ones) of the success of design language, along with the technology challenges that we were already facing
body.information2: However, in collaboration with my PM and the supporting development teams, we wanted to use this opportunity to bring in analytical data that we can use to drive better decisions. Using a new A/B testing platform built by one of the engineers, we ran two tests against the current design.

body.title: Results
body.information: Over the course of a controlled amount of time, we incrementally boosted live traffic to A/B test the two designs. I panicked with my PM because if both test failed, it would mean the end to our ambitions. To our delight, Test B came out with overwhelming results. By the final day, the initial test saw a 24% increase in conversions with 99% confidence in statistical significance.
body.imageDesc: While synthesizing the results, we realized there were too many uncontrolled components in our test for us to figure what to improve further. We still did not know just exactly what aspects was working and what was not.
body.imageTitle2: Do you already have a Capital One account?
body.imageDesc2: A key screen that attributed to our success was asking if customers already have a Capital One account with us. This screen allowed us to redirect applicants to the correct application. I worked with our content strategist to continue testing for improved language.
body.imageTitle3: Restructuring the Way Information was Presented
body.imageDesc3: The previous application asked for sensitive information upfront, such as the Social Security number. By pushing the Social Security number further into the application, we played with the idea that can ease our customers in by asking less sensitive information first.

body.title: More A/B Testing: Measuring Desirability
body.information: To build a truly unified experience, we wanted to explore the idea of allowing customers open multiple accounts at the same time. Learning from the successes of our past experience, we wanted to run a low risk A/B test in order to gain momentum.
body.information2: If a customer were to successfully open up a product, we would allow them to add on an additional product – similar to how candy is placed at the grocery check out.
body.imageDesc: We focused on the fact that it’s fee-free and won’t cost the customer anything to open an additional account. The interstitial would appear if a customer were qualified, and have just completed opening a new account with us.

body.information: We understand content is king. In order to figure out the right things to say at the right time, we work with data analysts to figure out the exact scroll position in which a prospective customer would drop off.
body.information2: We want to take our application and apply humanity into the interface. Working with legal and compliance, we want to ensure customers understand all the complicated bank terminology. We didn’t want any of that bank jargon. We are ready to take the design even further.
body.imageDesc: We documented and gained insights from well known financial apps along with gaining insights from a research team that provided an analysis of the top banks and their account opening process.
body.imageDesc2: As we gained insights on responsive web, I would apply them to our Android experience as well. Partnering with various development teams and designers, I currently lead the Android account opening efforts.

body.title: Epilogue
body.information: By March 2018, account opening had already created impacts across the organization. At one point, we had to withhold the full launch of our experience as our system was not ready to handle the increase in traffic.
body.information2: Through building close relationships with product and engineering, I was given more flexibility to provide a voice for the customer experience. I continue to provide design assets to many small, but impactful A/B tests across the application. I now work with various designers across different aspects of the application.
body.information3: All the insights we are gaining from A/B testing while simutaneously running userlabs to ask ‘why’ are driving a brand new redesign of account opening that is currently in development.

frontdescription: How we designed account opening so associates can focus on building branch relationships.

detaildescription: An app that lets you quickly upload, tag, and share your stuff effortlessly.

body.title: Prologue
body.information: If there was any project that defined a significant catalyst in my career, it was this one. Ruksak was a project I worked on while studying design at RIT. I had just completed an internship at a digital agency that helped shape a foundation in learning to understand the user, refining usability flows, and creating wireframes. However, I was severely lacking in good execution.
body.information2: Ruksak was one of the projects that taught me user interface design, how to utilize photography, and designing with Material Design in mind. The assignment was to ideate on a photosharing app, and I chose to design a service that allowed users to find inspiration from those around them.

body.title: Brief
body.information: Share and be inspired. There's already a ton of blogs out there to list out everything people carry with them on a daily basis, but there isn't a very quick way of doing it. RukSak lets users quickly snap pictures of items, tag them, post, and share.

body.title: Exploring a Need
body.information: Social media is saturated with various blogs from users that post about the items that they have. Most users use existing platforms such as Instagram and Tumblr to list out what they carry with them on a daily basis. However, there was no niche app dedicated to them particular usage of social media.

body.title: Visual Language
body.information: I chose pastel tones with the intention of building desire. Pastels have a calming effect that feed to our desire for spring. It is warm. It is calming, and it makes us feel happy and tranquil.
body.information2: By identifying the psychological effects of these colors, I can create a subconcious feeling of desire and inspire users to purchase items.

detaildescription: How do we design with health care data to better aid our doctors and nurses?

body.title: Prologue
body.information: Infirmary was a concept app during my college years while studying design. The challenge was to utilize big data to create an app. I was fascinated by the idea of data being readily available to solve problems, and the health industry was something I was intrigued by.
body.information2: The health industry needs a lot of modernization. I was frustrated by the long waits at hospitals and how dreadfully slow the entire process was. This project is about how data would be utilized to increase efficiency in health care.

body.title: Brief
body.information: Infirmary is a concept app in which electronic health records exist. How can we create an app that would utilize data to better serve doctors and patients?

body.title: Waiting at the Emergency Room
body.information: While working on this project, I also had the unfortunate experience of making frequent trips to the emergency room. My non-English speaking grandmother was going through some troubling times and had to frequently be admitted.
body.information2: I was able to get first hand experience of the process. Before a patient even get to speak to a medical professional, there was a need to validate patient’s information, insurance, paper work etc. We generally waited hours (and sometimes for an upward to six hours) before a doctor would speak to my grandmother.
body.information3: Patients are prioritized based on the severity of the problem. There are generally limited amount of doctors, but that doesn’t negate the pain that each of the patient in the emergency room are suffering from.

body.title: Documenting Issues & Ideation
body.information: While waiting at the emergency room with my grandmother, I often documented the problems that I would face, while brainstorming potential solutions. I noticed the doctors would always check the vitals first, and more than often, the doctor would be asking for a brief of the patient’s information from one of the nurses.
body.imageTitle: Ideation: How can we use big data to aid doctors and patients?
body.imageDesc: Allowing instant real-time patient vitals was one of the data points I focused on. This would allow doctors to always be able to access their patient’s vitals in order to keep track of their health.
body.imageTitle2: Moodboard: Fast, Futuristic, and Data Driven
body.imageDesc2: Infirmary is about fast, accurate information that is easily accessible by doctors. I wanted to use high contrast colors over dark backgrounds to truly push the information in front of it’s users.

body.title: Visual Prototypes
body.information: The design prioritizes communication and the transfer of information. Doctors can view past blood exams, xrays, medication, or medical devices of their patient to create a better diagnosis.
body.imageDesc: Just like how we can quickly glance over the weather each morning, information is display in a way that is quick and simple to read allows doctors to retrieve health stats with a single glance.
body.imageDesc2: We waiting for a lab test, and then wait for the lab result, and then waiting for the doctor to review the result. Things move very slowly. By digitizing documentations, and sharing data between medical employees, we can expediate the process so patients can be served quickly.

body.title: Epilogue (2018)
body.information: Although I didn’t realize it at the time, this project taught me the true value of design. Good designs aren’t just beautiful and easy to use interfaces (as I thought it was during my early years of college). Good designs are solutions to problems, and when solutions are well executed, they create beauty.
body.information2: I learned to study how doctors and patients interacted with one another while waiting at the emergency room. Today I’m studying how customers interact with bankers at Capital One branches and Cafes to improve the digital account opening experience. Both experiences are proving that the full experience isn’t always just online, and that digital experiences should be created to enhance the physical experience.
